title: New Specialized Roubaix goes all-road with 40mm clearance and extra mounts
content:
Cyclist
New Specialized Roubaix goes all-road with 40mm clearance and extra mounts

While the marketing tagline for the new Specialized Roubaix might be ‘The Science of Smooth’, the mantra of Specialized’s engineers might well have been, If it ain’t broke… Because while the bike boasts useful updates that take it further into all-road territory, this is less a design reinvented as it is re-refined. It comes hot on the heels of new Tarmac SL8 race bike, which Specialized released at the 2023 Road World Championships.

As per the previous generation Roubaix, the Future Shock front suspension system, flexy Pavé seatpost and aero credentials are still present, it’s just Specialized has sought to make everything just that little bit better in pursuit of a single goal:

‘This Roubaix is still that paradigm shift bike,’ says Specialized’s UK product manager, Richard Salaman. ‘The one that 20 years ago showed you can have comfort and performance.’

The new Roubaix is available now and will be offered in a wide range, with prices starting from £2,500 for the Base build, rising to £12,000 for the S-Works tier bike.

New Future Shock

Future Shock – the front suspension unit sandwiched between stem and head tube – has been the Roubaix’s calling card since 2016, and this time around things seem no different. Future Shock 3.0 offers the same 20mm of axial travel and its internals are the same, but dig a little deeper and subtle changes have been made.

First, while the last Roubaix came specced with Future Shock 1.5 (coil spring) or 2.0 (coil spring, hydraulic damper, adjustment dial), the new Future Shock 3.0 comes in three guises.

Future Shock 3.1 (specced on Roubaix Sport 105, Sport Apex and Base models) uses a coil spring for uncontrolled damping. Future Shock 3.2 (Roubaix Expert and Comp) uses a coil spring and a hydraulic damper to control shock progression and rebound. Future Shock 3.3 (S-Works and Pro) uses a coil spring, hydraulic damper and on-the-fly adjustment dial, a twisty knob which sits where the headset top cap usually is, and which incrementally changes spring rate (essentially how easy/hard it is to compress the shock).

All three are now set up to have less sag – that is, with a rider aboard, the coil and/or hydraulic cartridge compresses less, leaving more travel to work through.

Future Shock 3.1 is therefore very similar to the original Future Shock 1.0/1.5, while Future Shock 3.3 is very similar to the Future Shock 2.0 on the previous generation Roubaix, except tuneability has changed.

‘The older Future Shock dial had 12 clicks [changing the spring rate from soft to firm], but Future Shock 3.3 has five clicks,’ says Salaman. ‘Rider feedback said that splitting the spring rate across 12 indexed points meant each “click” didn’t feel like enough of a change, so we’ve kept the range but changed it to five incremental positions.’

(It should be noted that despite the apparent range of adjustment on the old Future Shock 2.0, the system essentially had just two states according to Specialized – open or firm. The brand assures us that the new Future Shock 3.3 adjuster has five distinct settings.)

As per the previous generation Future Shocks there is still no absolute lockout – the suspension is always active to some degree, albeit a very small amount in the firmest setting. But the rationale is, ‘Why would you want to turn it off?’

‘Future Shock isolates the rider from bumps without messing with geometry,’ says Salaman. ‘Imagine if a rider pulls the front brake on a descent – traditional suspension compresses, meaning the head tube dives, effectively changing the head angle, and therefore the handling suddenly changes in a way that can really unsettle a rider.’

Future Shock means the Roubaix’s geometry doesn’t change when the suspension moves as the fork stays in the same place in respect of the head tube.

Other Future Shock updates are even more subtle. There are now three coil spring options of different firmness, ordered based on rider weight, and confident home mechanics won’t need to take the bike to a Specialized dealer to change the spring over. Each bike ships with the three spring options.

Riders can also change the preload across Future Shocks 3.1, 3.2 and 3.3 by inserting washers (supplied) into the spring assembly (which influences sag); likewise the bike ships with two headset spacers, 10mm and 20mm, which can be changed over easily at home.

Things are a bit different for Future Shock 3.2 owners though. The hydraulical damper can be tuned à la Future Shock 3.3, but this technically needs to be done by a dealer as the unit needs to be disassembled. That said, it’s likely most savvy home mechanics could do this themselves, and furthermore, since the 3.3 and 3.2 internals are the same, were an aftermarket dial adjuster ever to be released, there’s no reason it couldn’t be retro-fitted, giving a Specialized Roubaix Expert or Pro owner the same performance up front as a S-Works bike.

Tuned up frame

Geometry is unchanged, and stack this 2024 Roubaix up against the previous generation and the bikes’ silhouettes are remarkably similar. But this one is different. The tube profiles have received aero tweaks, with re-sculpted fork legs, deeper down tube and even lower seatstays.

Tyre clearance has increased from 33mm to 40m, and elsewhere there are nods to greater utility, with the inclusion of mudguard mounts (reducing max tyre size to 35mm), a third set of bottle cage bosses on the underside of the down tube, and mounting points for a top tube bag.

Another carry-over is the D-shaped Pavé seatpost, which still offers 20mm of rearward flex. Although the seatstays now join the seat tube much lower than before, the seatpost clamp – set deep inside the seat tube – is in the same position, and it’s this clamping point that dictates how much seatpost is available to flex. The boxy section in the seat tube merely provides the space for the seatpost to bend backwards inside the frame; the rubber grommet on top is just a seal, not an elastomer.

In this, the seatpost holds the same brief as the Future Shock – isolate the rider from bumps without changing the geometry of the bike.

Another subtle but happy enough change is weight. The S-Works frame, made from top-tier Fact 12r carbon, weighs approximately 850g (size 56cm), while the Fact 10r base, Sport, Comp, Expert and Pro frames weigh 1,000g. That means full build weights start from 7.3kg, rising to 9.46kg.
